quantityRules.description: Corn snakes are solitary and do NOT tolerate cohabitation. House individually only - minimum 120 gallons (48√ó24√ó24 inches). Cohabitation causes chronic stress, competition for resources, disease transmission, and feeding aggression.

careTargets.gradient: Horizontal thermal gradient required (90¬∞F basking surface ‚Üí 75¬∞F cool zone)

lifespan: 20-25 years in captivity with proper care
temperament: Gentle and curious, rarely defensive, great for beginners
setupTips: PVC front-opening enclosures ideal - hold humidity better than glass, easier access
Use halogen flood bulbs (90w PAR38 x2) as PRIMARY heat source - heat mats supplemental only
Soil-based substrate (ReptiSoil, DIY 40/40/20 mix) 3-4 inches deep for humidity retention
BOTH warm hide (under basking) AND cool hide (opposite end) are mandatory
Provide 3-4 sturdy climbing branches at different heights - corn snakes are semi-arboreal
Large water bowl (8-10 inch diameter) on cool side for soaking
Basking surface temp (90¬∞F) measured with infrared thermometer, NOT ambient air temp
notes: Crepuscular (most active at sunset/dawn) - NOT fully nocturnal as commonly believed
Semi-arboreal - spend significant time climbing branches and exploring elevated areas
Very docile and handleable - rarely bite unless extremely stressed
Expert escape artists - secure locking lids essential (can push through weak screen tops)
Adult size: 3-5 feet (males smaller 3-4 feet, females larger 4-5 feet)
Over 800 morphs available due to extensive captive breeding
Native to southeastern United States, parts of Mexico, and Cayman Islands

warnings.message: Secure enclosure with locking lid REQUIRED - corn snakes are expert escape artists and can push through clips, lift screen tops, or squeeze through tiny gaps. Use cage locks or weighted lids.
BASKING SURFACE temp must be 90¬∞F measured with infrared thermometer on branch/rock surface. Ambient air temps are 10-15¬∞F cooler than surfaces. Low basking temps (<85¬∞F) prevent proper digestion.
Cohabitation is NOT safe despite being commonly attempted. Causes chronic stress, feeding aggression (documented cannibalism cases), disease transmission, and competition. Always house individually.
No handling for 48-72 hours after feeding - movement causes regurgitation. Snake needs stillness to digest. Regurgitation damages esophagus and requires 10-14 day fasting period to recover.
Humidity measured at substrate level (65-75%) - NOT top of enclosure. Use digital hygrometer probe placed on substrate. Low humidity (<60%) causes stuck sheds and dehydration.

40-gallon enclosures are OUTDATED advice from 1990s-2000s. Modern standard is 120 gallons (48√ó24√ó24) minimum based on snake length √ó 0.5 √ó 0.5 formula. Larger enclosures do NOT stress snakes if proper hides provided.

Heat mats are supplemental ONLY - never use as primary heat source. Can't achieve 90¬∞F basking surface temp or warm air properly. Use halogen flood bulbs overhead as primary heat (mimics natural sunlight).

feedingRequirements: Obligate carnivore - whole prey animals ONLY (mice, young rats, young quail, quail eggs, chicks, green anoles)
VARIETY ESSENTIAL - rotate prey types to prevent picky eating and provide balanced nutrition
Frozen-thawed strongly preferred over live (safer for snake, more humane for prey)
10% body weight rule: Prey item(s) should total 10% of snake's weight
Prey size: No larger than 1.5x snake's width at widest point
Thaw prey in warm water (100¬∞F) for 20-60 minutes, never microwave
feedingSchedule: Hatchlings (0-12 months): Every 7-10 days, 10% body weight (pinky to fuzzy mice)
Juveniles (12-24 months): Every 7-14 days, 10% body weight (hopper mice to small adult mice)
Adults (2+ years): Every 14-21 days, 10% body weight (adult mice or young rats)
Weigh snake monthly to adjust portions - visible ribs = underfed, rounded body = healthy, fat rolls = overfed
waterNotes: Large water bowl essential - must be large enough for snake to curl up inside completely
Water bowl placement: Cool side (prevents excessive evaporation)
Change water DAILY (corn snakes often defecate in water bowls)
Scrub bowl with reptile-safe disinfectant 2-3x weekly
Bowl depth: 2-3 inches minimum for soaking
Corn snakes soak 1-3 hours before shedding (normal behavior)
mistingNotes: Mist 1-2x daily in moderate climates, 2-3x daily in dry climates
Target: 65-75% humidity at substrate level (measured with hygrometer probe)
During shed cycle: Increase misting to achieve 70-75% humidity
Soil-based substrate (3-4 inches deep) is PRIMARY humidity management tool
Optional humid hide: Plastic hide box with damp sphagnum moss maintains 70-80% microclimate
Leaf litter layer on top of substrate helps retain moisture
